subject: Programming
title: NP-Complete Problems
description: A micro-lesson that makes NP-Complete Problems usable.

hook.text: In the 1970s, Stephen Cook and Leonid Levin discovered a class of problems all equally hard.

buildup.text: NP-complete problems are the hardest in NP. Solving one efficiently would solve them all.

discovery.text: Hundreds of real problems â€” scheduling, routing, packing â€” are NP-complete.

twist.text: If one falls, they all fall. Decades of trying suggests none of them will.

climax.text: When you prove a problem is NP-complete, you're saying: give up on perfection, approximate.

punchline.text: Proving something is hard is itself a useful answer.

quiz.question: What happens if you solve one NP-complete problem efficiently?
options: Only that one problem is solved
